metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python Inheritance
Python Inheritance
Inheritance allows us to define a class that inherits all the methods and properties from another class.
content.html: Inheritance allows us to define a class that inherits all the methods and properties from another class.

content.text: Parent class is the class being inherited from, also called base class.
content.html: Parent class is the class being inherited from, also called base class.

content.text: Child class is the class that inherits from another class, also called derived class.
content.html: Child class is the class that inherits from another class, also called derived class.

content.text: Create a Parent Class
Any class can be a parent class, so the syntax is the same as creating any other class:
content.html: Any class can be a parent class, so the syntax is the same as creating any other class:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
#Use the Person class to create an object, and then 
  execute the printname method:

syntax_highlighting.text:
#Use the Person class to create an object, and then 
  execute the printname method:

content.code_html:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    self.firstname = fname
    self.lastname = lname

  def printname(self):
    print(self.firstname, self.lastname)

#Use the Person class to create an object, and then execute the printname method:

x = Person("John", "Doe")
x.printname()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
#Use the Person class to create an object, and then 
  execute the printname method:

content.text: Create a Child Class
To create a class that inherits the functionality from another class, send the parent class as a parameter when creating the child class:
content.html: To create a class that inherits the functionality from another class, send the parent class as a parameter when creating the child class:

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  pass

content.text: Note: Use the pass keyword when you do not want to add any other properties or methods to the class.
content.html: Note: Use the pass keyword when you do not want to add any other properties or methods to the class.

content.text: Now the Student class has the same properties and methods as the Person class.
content.html: Now the Student class has the same properties and methods as the Person class.

content.code_html:
x = Student("Mike", "Olsen")
x.printname()

content.text: Add the __init__() Function
So far we have created a child class that inherits the properties and methods from its parent.
content.html: So far we have created a child class that inherits the properties and methods from its parent.

content.text: We want to add the __init__() function to the child class (instead of the pass keyword).
content.html: We want to add the __init__() function to the child class (instead of the pass keyword).

content.text: Note: The __init__() function is called automatically every time the class is being used to create a new object.
content.html: Note: The __init__() function is called automatically every time the class is being used to create a new object.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
  #add properties etc.

content.code:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
#add properties etc.

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
 #add properties etc.

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    #add properties etc.

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
  #add properties etc.

content.text: When you add the __init__() function, the child class will no longer inherit the parent's __init__() function.
content.html: When you add the __init__() function, the child class will no longer inherit the parent's __init__() function.

content.text: Note: The child's __init__() function overrides the inheritance of the parent's __init__() function.
content.html: Note: The child's __init__() function overrides the inheritance of the parent's __init__() function.

content.text: To keep the inheritance of the parent's __init__() function, add a call to the parent's __init__() function:
content.html: To keep the inheritance of the parent's __init__() function, add a call to the parent's __init__() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
  Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

content.code:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
  Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
  Person.__init__(self, fname, lname)

content.text: Now we have successfully added the __init__() function, and kept the inheritance of the parent class, and we are ready to add functionality in the __init__() function.
content.html: Now we have successfully added the __init__() function, and kept the inheritance of the parent class, and we are ready to add functionality in the __init__() function.

content.text: Use the super() Function
Python also has a super() function that will make the child class inherit all the methods and properties from its parent:
content.html: Python also has a super() function that will make the child class inherit all the methods and properties from its parent:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
    super().__init__(fname, lname)

content.code:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
super().__init__(fname, lname)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
 super().__init__(fname, lname)

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname):    
    super().__init__(fname, lname)

content.text: By using the super() function, you do not have to use the name of the parent element, it will automatically inherit the methods and properties from its parent.
content.html: By using the super() function, you do not have to use the name of the parent element, it will automatically inherit the methods and properties from its parent.

content.text: Add Properties

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)
    self.graduationyear = 2019

content.text: In the example below, the year 2019 should be a variable, and passed into the Student class when creating student objects. To do so, add another parameter in the __init__() function:
content.html: In the example below, the year 2019 should be a variable, and passed into the Student class when creating student objects. To do so, add another parameter in the __init__() function:

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)
    self.graduationyear = year

x = Student("Mike", "Olsen", 2019)

content.text: Add Methods

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):    
  super().__init__(fname, lname)    self.graduationyear 
  = year  def welcome(self):    print("Welcome", 
  self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

content.code:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):
super().__init__(fname, lname)    self.graduationyear
= year  def welcome(self):    print("Welcome",
self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

syntax_highlighting.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):    
 super().__init__(fname, lname)    self.graduationyear 
  = year  def welcome(self):    print("Welcome", 
  self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

content.code_html:
class Student(Person):
  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):
    super().__init__(fname, lname)
    self.graduationyear = year

  def welcome(self):
    print("Welcome", self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Student(Person):  def __init__(self, fname, lname, year):    
  super().__init__(fname, lname)    self.graduationyear 
  = year  def welcome(self):    print("Welcome", 
  self.firstname, self.lastname, "to the class of", self.graduationyear)

content.text: If you add a method in the child class with the same name as a function in the parent class, the inheritance of the parent method will be overridden.
content.html: If you add a method in the child class with the same name as a function in the parent class, the inheritance of the parent method will be overridden.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the correct keyword to use inside an empty class, to avoid getting an error?
content.html: What is the correct keyword to use inside an empty class, to avoid getting an error?
